item.title: üåª Puma 6.0 released
item.description:
#‚Äã625 ‚Äî October 20, 2022

Read on the Web üá∫üá¶
Together with¬†

Ruby Weekly

Finding Relationships Between Ruby‚Äôs Top 100 Packages and Their¬†Dependencies ‚Äî RubyGems recently began rolling out a new security policy for protecting the most heavily used gems, but what about the dependencies of those gems? Kevin got to work using the (very useful) RubyGems data dumps and found that ‚Äò24 of the 112 big gems rely on small gems‚Äô but really the journey is more interesting than the outcome¬†here.

Kevin Lin

Puma 6.0 'Sunflower' Released ‚Äî Puma is arguably the leading HTTP server for Rack based apps right now and 6.0 is a significant release with overall performance improvements, experimental Rack 3 support, support for Sidekiq 7 ‚Äòcapsules‚Äô, and more. Note that Ruby 2.2 and 2.3 support has been¬†dropped.

Puma Contributors

Free eBook: Advanced Database Programming with Rails and Postgres ‚Äî Learn about subqueries, materialized views, and custom data types in Postgres and Rails. We walk through realistic real-life examples, translating first into SQL, and then into Rails code. Every example comes with source code so you can follow¬†along.

pganalyze sponsor

DHH and Basecamp: "Why We're Leaving The Cloud" ‚Äî Rails‚Äô creator David Heinemeier Hansson is also CTO at Basecamp, 37signals or whatever it‚Äôs called this week, and as a prettttty significant Ruby and Rails shop, it‚Äôs interesting to see his take on the cloud vs self hosting. David Heinemeier Hansson

‚úâÔ∏è ¬†The Short Ruby Newsletter ‚Äî A newsletter that's not by us! But don‚Äôt be fooled, it‚Äôs actually waaaay longer than Ruby Weekly but does a good job of digging up Ruby related tips, opinion and discussion from Twitter in¬†particular. A good way to keep up with tips and chatter while we stick to the boring stuff ;-)

Lucian Ghinda

Improving Your Code with RubyCritic ‚Äî RubyCritic is a meta-tool for producing reports about Ruby code quality. It uses other tools like Reek, SimpleCov, Flay, and Flog to produce reports about things like complexity, code smells, and test¬†coverage.

Evil Martians

Andy Croll
